Language: Version:
Inspira Uploadable Application Form
Version:
Warning: The United Nations is aware of various schemes being circulated via e-mail, regular mail and fax, falsely stating that they are issued by or
associated with the United Nations. Please note that the United Nations only accepts applications uploaded through the inspira online recruitment
system. Email applications will not be accepted.
Welcome!
This form is available to offer the flexibility of preparing an offline application for job openings posted in inspira.
You can complete your initial application using this form. Your data will be then stored in inspira and can be used
for any future applications.
Please note that the offline application template does not include accessibility features such as the ability to
function with a wide range of standard assistive technologies (e.g. screen readers and alternative keyboards). To
have full access to these accessibility features, please apply through the inspira online page and turn on the
"Accessibility" button.
Note: Complete this form using Adobe Acrobat Reader version 9.1 or above. Also make sure you have the latest
version of this form since only the latest version can be uploaded in inspira.
To apply for job openings using this form, please follow the steps shown below:
1. Complete this form and save it to your computer with the existing file name. Complete the form ensuring
that you fill out all required sections which are marked with asterisk (*). Make sure to fill out all Work
Experience and Education Details
2. Log into inspira (https://inspira.un.org)
3. It is very important that you first ensure that your contact information (including your e-mail address and
phone number) is current and correct. If we cannot reach you at the e-mail or phone number provided,
you may not be considered further for the job opening to which you are applying. If you need to update
your contact information, please do it online in inspira by clicking on the “My Profile” tab in your inspira
applicant activity center (home page).
4. After updating your profile, go back to your inspira applicant activity center. Using the inspira job search
tool, locate and open the required job opening and then click on “Apply Now”.
5. Under the "Welcome" section, select the "Load from File" option, then upload your completed Offline
Application Template form.
6. Once the template has been uploaded successfully, click on "Next".
7. Answer the Job Requirements Questions specific to the job opening and validate each section of your
application.
8. Under the “Other information” tab, upload relevant file(s) here (e.g., two latest performance management
documents for UN staff). For applications to locally recruited staff positions in the General Service or
related categories, please upload one or more documents (e.g., passport, work permit) that indicate your
right to work in the duty station you are applying to.
9. When you are ready to submit your application, click on the “Review/Submit” tab and review all sections.
10. Click on “Submit Application”. Immediately after submitting your application, its status on the “My
Application” page should be “Applied”.

deemed appropriate during the selection process.

messages.content:
Based on your resume, you have an impressive background in education, innovation, and entrepreneurship, especially in the SWANA region. To help determine if you would be a good fit for this UN position and how to frame your application, let me ask you a few questions:

1. Motivation: What aspects of this specific UN role most inspire and motivate you to apply? How does it align with your professional goals and values?

2. Relevant Experience: Could you elaborate on 1-2 of your past experiences that you feel are most relevant to the requirements of this UN position? What key skills and learnings would you bring from those roles?

3. Unique Contribution: Considering the UN's mission and the specific objectives of this role, what unique perspectives, skills or experiences do you have that would allow you to make a significant positive impact in this position?

Reflecting deeply on these questions should help you craft a compelling motivation statement and identify the most pertinent parts of your background to highlight in the application. The UN values  lived experience, diversity of thought, entrepreneurial drive, and commitment to humanitarian causes - which your resume demonstrates. Framing your application around your first-hand knowledge of challenges in the region, passion for empowering marginalized communities, and track record of innovative program design and delivery could make for a strong application. Let me know if you would like me to elaborate on any part of the application further as you complete it.

messages.content:
To ansewr the first question: here is my resume and here is a short bio i'm working on: I am bilal Ghalib, an Iraqi american with an Iraqi passport recently aquired. I have worked hard on it since 2018 because ever since I was young, I felt the beauty of my father's opportunity to be in us and the pain of watching my cousins live through such difficulty. I felt a calling in high school; this is all connected; the difficulty there is related to the ease I am living in America. When people like my father leave and contribute their amazing skills something important has left the country of Iraq and i promised myself when I had that insight that i would become a bridge builder, I didn't know if I could ever return yet I wanted to do what i could to bridge worlds, like me, American <->Iraqi Iraqi <-> american how could we bring more equality of opportunity to the world so that people like my father could dream of a future where they would be able to stay in the land they love? It didn't become clear till I graduated college, witnessed the Arab Spring, and saw young people around my age taking to the street, wanting a better future and a country they would be proud of. Their belief was a political change; at that moment, I was working on propagating what I had called PBLEs - passion-based learning environments; others know them as maker spaces, fab labs, etc. I started one in Michigan called All Hands Active and realized there's another way to a better future: make it yourself. It's a bit libertarian, yet working as an outsider in the Middle East and being less politically motivated were assets. I raised my funds from Kickstarter as the world was ready to bring this idea to fruition. That was what led me to create GEMSI (the global entrepreneurship and maker space initiative) to help establish collectivly organized spaces for learning and development. While i started mostly in the technical space I quickly realized that some of the most important parts of building comes before putting pen to paper. it comes with intention. why are people doing this? one day there was a 3 car car bomb blast in iraq and i was there - the hackerspace community that i was so hopeful would be a beacon of hope and responding with care and wondering how they could help simply said "we'll do our show and tell next week" of course that's the only sane thing to do when there is a car bomb every 3 days. i made a "song" to visuzlize the frequency of the attacks where the high hat on the drums represented the days and the base drum represented bombs with the intensity of the base being the number of the dead. It made my blood turn to ice. I couldn't imagine being the the organizers of fikra space (hackerspace in iraq's name of org) living in iraq throught that period 2003-2014 and caring for every bomb. yet i decided i wanted to connect my work with goodness and realized that what i was hleping was to bring what is inside people out into the world. creativity + skill = production of art, projects, etc. and one of my foundational beliefs is that people are good

if i didn't believe that then i wouldn't be able to live, we are good, we have the capacity of good and when we open the door inward and understand ourselves and motivations and don't act on blind impulse - we see how we really want to respond, which is with goodness when we see pain in the world. this is why i shifted my creativity and entrepreneurship work by giving peoplet echnical skills and encouraging people to start projects and businesses based on an abstract competency and "do what you love" or some random idea like that. I realized that if i really cared for people and their wellbeing and happiness i had to help them find a work that would bring them meaning and purpose. i had to understand what the underlying foundations of a true life of flourishing was. this coincided with me identifying my PTSD from working in Iraq and Syria and the work i did to heal helped me understand how we can be so ugly and how learning must include personal and professional learning - even for the simple matter that our professional efforts come from a very personal place, the self. Without self management professional management is useless. this brought me to start bloom.pm with my co-founder Munir. we started the organization to create custom learning journeys and to bridge personal and professional growth for social entrepreneurs and to build software to let people identify their primary growth areas and to find activities to develop in a learning by doing style. we were tired of seeing people go to another boot camp and do another "business model canvas" yet again without any real support of any depth or customizability so i used my background in computer science to make a custom learning by doing assessment and activity tool. you took a test and asked a few reflective questions with a Program manager and each person in the program had a custom learning journey that was special for them yet at the same time they had a cohort experience enjoying the process of learning and growing together. We buildthis for 6 years and i am now focusing deeply on what i see to be a huge potential for learning systems using AI and LLMs in particular. i believe it might be possible to reduce the inequality of access to high quality mentors by helping people identify things they didn't even know they needed to learn. mentors fill in blind spots, when you have a "map of everything" because the LLM has digested the entire public internet - you can find ways of teaching people to interrogate the LLM in a specific way to help auto-mentor themselves. I'm developing this framework and believe it is the next step of making education more accessible. initially you had to be a prince to have your own individual tutor helping tailor learning activities for them to learn and grow in a holistic way. then we slowly get mass learning so we can keep elites as elites and the masses just get graded like screws or meat "grade a" can take the land owners and capital owners a good return on their payment of salary. then ben franklin started the public library, the idea of public goods started becoming more of a thing, the ability to have mobility in class started, people who take initiative to go to the library and get books. then from that we get the internet and knowledge was in our pockets. we are oppressed by ads and distraction where the powers that owned want to sustain ownership, it's now automated and digitized and faster and ETFified - yet the fundamental force at play is value sucked into capital, including attention, the foundation of learning. terrifiying. i believe though it doesn't catch everyone. and within the system people fight back. there are instagram ads designed to help people get off instaram. and the truth of the goodness and kindness and meaning seeking part of the human being wanting expression, realizing death is coming, the rise of suicides and the mirror of it being terrorism. the nihlistic attitude that comes from the numbness of stolen everything. when you can't focus, when you haven't been taught how to learn, when your time isn't yours, and you are distracted from cradle to the grave by suggestions for purchases at every turn. this is why i believe we can use LLMs to go back to having everyone their own custom tutor. valuing the preciousness that is within humanity that is good, that knows goodness, and that wants to enact goodness. the thing that knows goodness is the thing that wants to respond to knowledge with goodness and the thing that motivates us to access knowledge.

Help me come up with a statement

2) my relevant experience right now at bloom is the head of reserach and development where i focus on learning and designing our pedagogy and frameworks for learning how to learn using LLMs and the training manuals and training of the trainers and writing grants and teaching the teachers by running an accelerator for accelerators pitching those ideas and presenting and facilitating and managing online sessions and in person sessions and relationships with funders, teams, clients, team memebrs, I'm also a founder so there's all the founder stuff of team management etc

3.  i am an iraqi american who speaks iraqi who's worked on building some of the earliest learning by doing spaces in the country (fikra space) and is the "grandfather" of the movement if people know it or not, that's special. i'm also a fast learner and have worked on pedagogy since 2016 and innovation in learning i have a masters degree in learning sciences from the university of paris where i studied post traumatic growth for young entrepreneurs working in the middle east - probably relevant for this job in iraq with youth - if you want the paper i wrote i can share it in the next prompt im' sure there's tons of stuff that makes me super perfect for this role. the only issue i can see is i don't have ocnstruction background. oh they want someone with finance skills i have started businesses since highschool maybe ... 6 at the very least businesses

Without self management professional management is useless. this brought me to start bloom.pm with my co-founder Munir. we started the organization to create custom learning journeys and to bridge personal and professional growth for social entrepreneurs and to build software to let people identify their primary growth areas and to find activities to develop in a learning by doing style. we were tired of seeing people go to another boot camp and do another "business model canvas" yet again without any real support of any depth or customizability so i used my background in computer science to make a custom learning by doing assessment and activity tool. you took a test and asked a few reflective questions with a Program manager and each person in the program had a custom learning journey that was special for them yet at the same time they had a cohort experience enjoying the process of learning and growing together. We buildthis for 6 years and i am now focusing deeply on what i see to be a huge potential for learning systems using AI and LLMs in particular. i believe it might be possible to reduce the inequality of access to high quality mentors by helping people identify things they didn't even know they needed to learn. mentors fill in blind spots, when you have a "map of everything" because the LLM has digested the entire public internet - you can find ways of teaching people to interrogate the LLM in a specific way to help auto-mentor themselves. I'm developing this framework and believe it is the next step of making education more accessible. initially you had to be a prince to have your own individual tutor helping tailor learning activities for them to learn and grow in a holistic way. then we slowly get mass learning so we can keep elites as elites and the masses just get graded like screws or meat "grade a" can take the land owners and capital owners a good return on their payment of salary. then ben franklin started the public library, the idea of public goods started becoming more of a thing, the ability to have mobility in class started, people who take initiative to go to the library and get books. then from that we get the internet and knowledge was in our pockets. we are oppressed by ads and distraction where the powers that owned want to sustain ownership, it's now automated and digitized and faster and ETFified - yet the fundamental force at play is value sucked into capital, including attention, the foundation of learning. terrifiying. i believe though it doesn't catch everyone. and within the system people fight back. there are instagram ads designed to help people get off instaram. and the truth of the goodness and kindness and meaning seeking part of the human being wanting expression, realizing death is coming, the rise of suicides and the mirror of it being terrorism. the nihlistic attitude that comes from the numbness of stolen everything. when you can't focus, when you haven't been taught how to learn, when your time isn't yours, and you are distracted from cradle to the grave by suggestions for purchases at every turn. this is why i believe we can use LLMs to go back to having everyone their own custom tutor. valuing the preciousness that is within humanity that is good, that knows goodness, and that wants to enact goodness. the thing that knows goodness is the thing that wants to respond to knowledge with goodness and the thing that motivates us to access knowledge.

Help me come up with a statement

2) my relevant experience right now at bloom is the head of reserach and development where i focus on learning and designing our pedagogy and frameworks for learning how to learn using LLMs and the training manuals and training of the trainers and writing grants and teaching the teachers by running an accelerator for accelerators pitching those ideas and presenting and facilitating and managing online sessions and in person sessions and relationships with funders, teams, clients, team memebrs, I'm also a founder so there's all the founder stuff of team management etc

3.  i am an iraqi american who speaks iraqi who's worked on building some of the earliest learning by doing spaces in the country (fikra space) and is the "grandfather" of the movement if people know it or not, that's special. i'm also a fast learner and have worked on pedagogy since 2016 and innovation in learning i have a masters degree in learning sciences from the university of paris where i studied post traumatic growth for young entrepreneurs working in the middle east - probably relevant for this job in iraq with youth - if you want the paper i wrote i can share it in the next prompt im' sure there's tons of stuff that makes me super perfect for this role. the only issue i can see is i don't have ocnstruction background. oh they want someone with finance skills i have started businesses since highschool maybe ... 6 at the very least businesses

Here is a draft motivation statement for your UN application, drawing from your resume and additional background you provided:

Motivation Statement

As an Iraqi-American deeply committed to bridging divides and expanding opportunities, I am inspired to apply for this UN role to contribute my skills in education, innovation and entrepreneurship toward empowering marginalized youth in Iraq. 

Since high school, I have felt a strong calling to address the stark inequality between my privileged upbringing in the US and the immense challenges faced by my family in Iraq. Witnessing my father's journey and the wasted potential when talented people are forced to leave their homeland, I vowed to become a bridge-builder. The Arab Spring protests crystallized my resolve to support youth in creating their own solutions and rekindled futures.

For over a decade, I have worked to propagate "passion-based learning environments" and equip young people with creative and technical skills to improve their communities. I co-founded GEMSI to establish collaboratively-run makerspaces that have become a cornerstone of the maker movement in the Middle East. Through this, I developed a nuanced understanding of the Iraqi context and built trusted relationships with local partners.

However, I realized that truly transformative education must address the whole person. Healing from my own PTSD after working in conflict zones, I discovered the power of integrating personal and professional development. This insight shaped bloom.pm, the social enterprise I co-founded to design customized learning journeys that cultivate self-awareness, emotional intelligence and sense of purpose alongside practical competencies.

As head of R&D at bloom.pm, I lead pedagogy and program design, train facilitators, and forge partnerships with funders and ecosystem actors. Core to my work is leveraging AI language models to democratize access to high-quality, personalized mentorship at scale. I believe such cutting-edge tools, combined with experiential, community-embedded learning, can be game-changing for youth in Iraq.

My Iraqi heritage, Arabic fluency, on-the-ground experience building learning infrastructure amidst instability, and expertise in participatory program design and emerging technologies make me uniquely suited to help the UN deliver meaningful outcomes for Iraqi youth. I would be honored to bring my entrepreneurial approach, ability to bridge cultures, and steadfast commitment to the mission of empowering the next generation of changemakers.

Word count: 328

Let me know if you would like me to modify or expand on anything in this draft statement. I'm happy to refine it further.
